problem.tex: Let $f$ be a holomorphic function on the region $\Omega$ such that $f(\Omega)\cap\Omega\neq\emptyset$ and $f(f(z))=f(z)$. Prove $f$ is either constant or the identity.

solution.tex: Taking the derivative gives \[f'(z)=f'(f(z))f'(z).\] If $f$ is not constant then \[1=f'(f(z)).\] Again \[0=f''(f(z))f'(z).\] Remember $f$ is not constant, so this means $f''(f(z))$ constantly vanishes. Moreover, $f(\Omega)$ is open by the open mapping theorem, so $f''$ vanishes on an open set. The uniqueness principle states that $f''$ must then be constantly 0, so there are constants $a,b$ with \[f(z)=az+b.\] Solving the initial requirement is \[az+b=a(az+b)+b=a^2z+ab+b\] \[a^2z-az+ab=0\] \[a(az-z+b)=0.\] If $a$ were 0, $f$ would be constant. Thus we have assumed $a\neq0$. Then $az-z+b=0$ for all $z$. That is, \[z(a-1)=-b.\] If $a\neq1$ then this would state that the only complex number is $\frac{-b}{a-1}$, a clear falsehood. Thus $a$ must be 1. This forces $b$ to be 0 and $f$ to be the identity.
